title: Female ISIS cell jailed for failed plot to blow up car bomb outside Notre Dame cathedral
text:
An all female ISIS cell were jailed on Monday for up to 30 years for a failed plot to carry out a car bomb massacre outside Notre Dame Cathedral three years ago.

The five, aged between 22 and 42, were arrested after a car packed with gas cylinders was found parked near the bustling esplanade in front of the cathedral in the heart of the capital on November 4, 2016.

The two main defendants, Ines Madani and Ornella Gilligmann, had doused the car with diesel in the middle of the night and tried but failed to set it alight with a cigarette. They were sentenced to 30 years and 25 years in prison respectively.

The women are believed to have been acting on the orders of Rachid Kassim, a French Islamic State propagandist, also suspected of ordering the grisly murder of a French police couple at their home in June 2016.

The two main defendants, Ines Madani and Ornella Gilligmann, had doused the car (pictured) with diesel in the middle of the night and tried but failed to set it alight with a cigarette

ISIS killer Rachid Kassim, pictured, is thought to have orchestrated several attacks in France and claimed responsibility for the Nice truck attack in July 2016, issuing a chilling video message to Francois Hollande and slitting the throat of a prisoner

A courtroom sketch of Ines Madani, jailed for 30 years on Monday, the longest of any of the defendants

Kassim was the public face of ISIS' claim on the July 2016 Nice truck attack that left 86 people dead, appearing in a video in which he threatened France and beheaded a captive in Iraq.

His digital fingerprints were also smeared across the harrowing throat slitting of an elderly priest in the Normandy town of Saint-Etienne-du-Rouvray, also in July 2016.

Kassim, originally from Lyon, is believed to have been killed in an air strike near the Iraqi city of Mosul in February 2017.

Madani, 22, was arrested a few days after the failed attack in a Paris suburb along with two other defendants, Sarah Hervouet and Amel Sakaou, who were each sentenced to 20 years.

The three burst out of the apartment to which they had been tracked down by police, brandishing knives.

Hervouet stabbed an officer in the shoulder, while Madani was shot in the leg.

Gilligmann was arrested in southern France.

A fifth woman, Samia Chalel, was also tried for allegedly helping hide Madani. She was sentenced to five years in prison.

Video captured the moment a woman was detained after the discovery of a car packed with gas canisters left in central Paris

The flat the women were sharing was raided, Hervouet stabbed an officer in the shoulder, while Madani was shot in the leg

Left to right: Ines Madani, Ornella Gilligmann and Sarah Hervouet during their trial

The court heard how Madani posed as a male jihadist online to try recruit women for IS and won over Gilligmann in messages exchanged online.

Madani's lawyers described her as a lonely young woman with half-baked attack plans and a death wish - a far cry from the prosecution's characterisation of a determined gang of would-be killers.

Madani told the court on Monday she regretted her actions.

'At the time all my plans involved death. Today, my plans are about life,' she said.

French policemen take part in a police raid in Boussy-Saint-Antoine near Paris after the car was discovered in 2016

The abandoned car full of gas cylinders near Notre Dame is cordoned off by police in 2016

Kassim was the public face of an ISIS claim of responsibility for the July 14 truck attack on Nice that left 86 people dead, appearing in a video in which he threatened France and beheaded a captive in Iraq

Gilligmann, a married mother of three, spoke emotionally of the 'shame' she had brought on her family and asked for forgiveness from the victims of terrorism.

Her lawyers argued she had acted out of love for a fictitious jihadist named Abou Junayd, for whom she left her husband.

The case is the first to involve a group of women attempting to stage an attack in France, which has been repeatedly targeted by jihadists since 2015, causing the loss of 255 lives.
description: The five, aged between 22 and 42, were arrested after a car laden with gas cylinders was found parked in front of the cathedral in the heart of Paris on November 4, 2016.
